newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Strike to paralyse Ostend-Ramsgate weekend traffic.
newsitem.headline: Strike to paralyse Ostend-Ramsgate weekend traffic.

text.p: Ferry traffic between the ports of Ostend in Belgium and Ramsgate in England will be paralysed this weekend by a strike by personnel of Wagons-Lits, a unit of French hotel group Accor, working for Belgian state-owned Channel ferry operator RMT, unions said on Thursday.
"A general meeting (of the unions) decided to continue actions in the weekend of October 12 and call a general strike of Wagons-Lits personnel," a joint trade unions' statement said.
A similar strike was held last weekend.

Some 350 people from Wagons-Lits' shipping division are affected by the decision taken last month by the Belgian government to wind up RMT in 1999, leaving the Ramsgate to Ostend route to be run by Australia's Holyman Ltd and Sally Lines, a unit of Finland's Silja Oy.
Wagons-Lits personnel, fearing they will suffer more from RMT's demise than RMT's own workforce of 1,350, demand hard guarantees on employment and early retirement.
A transport ministry official said he was surprised by the actions because unions had been given guarantees of redeployment of staff during a meeting late on Wednesday.
RMT, hit by competition from other Channel ferry operators and the Channel Tunnel, has lost money every year since 1992 and has accumulated debts of 12 billion Belgian francs.
The government forecasts 1996's loss will be around three billion francs.
RTM/RMT is expected to lose a further 1.8 and 1.6 billion francs in 1997 and 1998. The Belgian government hopes to partly cover the losses by the sale of its ships and other assets.
